title: AMAA - Riot Games QA Careers and questions
body:
Hello I’m Sean ‘Dannamoth’ Radak joined by Chris ‘Riot Spider’ Buzon 

We're always looking for really talented people to join our QA team. Many of you probably don't know how we work or why we think QA at Riot is an awesome place to work, though!  With that said, we would like to open the thread to any questions you have for us about QA at Riot Games. To start the thread off we want to hit on a few different  popular questions. (Other folks working in the QA department will probably chime in as they have something to say/answer)


**1. What does QA do at Riot?**

The short answer is- “a bunch of things”. We have Game Analysts that live and breathe competitive League of Legends and work with our champion and gameplay design teams creating and modifying content. We have test engineers that build automation frameworks and assist us in driving on continuous delivery. We have QA leads that focus on the growth and mentorship of the analysts on the teams they work with. 

**2. What is your day like?**

Our general day to day activities will depend on the team you’re working on. Our core work hours are 10am-7pm. If you’re working on the Events QA team you will be supporting one of our many global esports events. This would include trips to Europe, various locations around the US, or any other manner of locations. Almost all of the QA at Riot are embedded on the teams they work with. Someone working with the Skins team is going to have a very different day than an Analyst working with the Patcher team. Some things that you might be doing throughout the day: Playtesting new champions or live balance changes, combing through the forums or reddit to hunt down any escaped bugs, participating in long term team planning, and test plan creation/execution.

**3. Do I need to be Challenger Tier to work at Riot?**

No, but that depends on what you want to do. Almost all of the QA Analysts  working with designers on live balance changes are platinum to challenger tier. Other positions don’t need to have mad League of Legends skills, but it never hurts. Almost all of the game focused QA positions are going to require a strong knowledge of the game. 

**4. Where is Riot Games?**

We’re lots of places, you can check out all the specific office locations on our careers page www.riotgames.com/careers . Our Headquarters are located in Santa Monica. We have open QA positions in Saint Louis, Santa Monica and a few other locations. If you’re interested in applying, please include this post and specifically reference “Dannamoth” in your cover letter, this will help us track those who apply!

Hey Riot,

Are there any technical or engineering positions available in QA? I love making things awesome, but I also love writing code!

Ames

Wow, so Blatent. 

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-djXiasOQL98/UbgrxGHXN9I/AAAAAAAAMQE/Z8K1V-_k5g0/s1600/allow-it.gif

Wow! Great question, Ames.

As it turns out, we're working on hiring a bunch of people in this exact area. What other companies might call SDET, SET, etc, is a career that we also think is important. League of Legends is a really big game with lots going on. In order to empower our developers, we also need to build automated testing systems, better tools, and more.

It's an interesting problem space that I'm really excited about and would love to talk more about!

Hey Ames,

Thanks for the interest. As a matter of fact, there *are* opportunities to be a badass coder in QA!

We have a technical career path that leads up to being something known as a Test Engineer, or similarly a "Software Developer in Test" (SDET for short). These roles involve fun challengese such as "How do we automated testing for League of Legends and the surrounding systems"? It is a pretty critical role to reliably shipping LoL to players every 2 weeks.

Other projects include writing awesome tools for our QA and Engineering folks that help improve their efficiency and workflow (examples: source control plugins, informational displays of internal development metrics, etc..).

An awesome part of this role is that there is a need for it in pretty much every area - Game, Platform/Backend, Web, Mobile... so you really get a lot of opportunities for learning different tech.

Reading through, I notice 'having a project to point to'  has been a consistent good bonus to any application. In your eyes what is a 'good project'? Can it be something as universal as a youtube channel or would you prefer a more specific and specialized project to consider it as a plus to a resume?

I use the term project because it encompasses multiple things. For example, someone I recently interviewed for a team had a jungle simulator that allowed you to plug in certain champions/runes/masteries and gave you how long certain routes would take. This allowed me to see his software writing skills and how he solved problems. It also showed me an element of his passion for League of Legends. 

If you think about it from the companies perspective we're trying to figure out if the person in the room with us has the skills to do the job we want to hire them for. For people who are working through or finished college, you might not have relevant work experience. How do you show you have experience? DO the thing you want to be doing for a company. If you want to work on live design? Break down champions/meta/design decisions and propose possible changes. Want to work on software? Write some software that does something.

Completely understandable, thank you for the reply!

Now as a tangential follow-up, how are teams broken up among the QA department? What are some of the most active and engaged teams currently?

And more specific, do you have any QA members working with the CB team and/or player relations? It's been an area of interest for me as I have been what I feel is very active on the CB and have (hopefully) a good reputation built up here among reds and players.

That's the thing! QA is embedded on the teams they work with. We don't have QA sequestered into some dark basement. We work super closely with developers and engineers to make sure that we're not only making objectively quality things, but subjectively awesome things. I just walked by a room with 2 champion designers and 2 QA bros working on a whiteboard over something. I believe the team working on skins/champions are super active when content they are working on first goes out to the PBE. I'm super active whenever a team I'm working with ships something. You will probably see me posting in the "patch day bug mega thread" every two weeks. 


Interacting with players is really up to everyone's discretion. No one is forced to post, but most everyone reads. I know we are pretty good about giving feedback to the team working on the CB boards. I'm pretty sure we have some Web QA folks working with the new site creation.

Not gonna lie that sounds pretty awesome. In that case, how is you guys determine internship positions? Do you have a slot saved on a team and look for "the right intern" or do you select interns based on a general "best of the best" criteria and try to place them where they would best fit?

Also, are there times when a single QA guy/gal works with multiple teams to make sure everything meshes? I consider myself very much a 'jack of all trades master of none' kind of guy. I write, design, critique, analyze, ideate and simply talk quite often and with a good amount of enthusiasm (espeically with League content) but I can't say I'm the best at any category. Is that uniquely useful in any way within the QA dept?

What is one of (in your opinion)the biggest challenges as a QA tester at riot?

From my personal experience, the amount of knowledge that you need to learn and relationships you need to build to be hyper effective is astounding. I wouldn't be effective at my job if I didn't build relationships with the right people so I knew who to talk to when something went wrong. "Oh yea, I remember the engineer that worked on that feature" has saved hours of time digging around in code to find something. 

Tangential to that is the cycle we work in. We ship new content and code every 2 weeks or so. We have to be very efficient with how we test and what we're testing.

For me, it's the amount of ownership we're able to have over what we're working on. We work as part of a team, of course, but we're responsible for making sure that the things we make are high quality and will meet player expectations. One of the best ways to do that is to support the developers we work with and help them improve their craft- they're all extremely capable on their own as is, but as a team we're that much more effective.

It's one my favorite aspects of the job!
If I somehow end up working this job, will I be able to slap unsuspecting players with the legendary 1RP like RiotAmes?
If you work on the right team and wield the power with the appropriate respect, it's a possibility!

**How would I best demonstrate my potential as a Game Analyst in order to attempt to get hired for that department, which no longer has a job listing?**

The best way to demonstrate potential for game analyst is to self-start and do projects. Build up your own projects that allow you to critically think and problem solve decisions as you go - and break down existing projects to understand why developers make decisions.

What about the Localisation QA jobs? Do you have any info on these positions imply?

Hi Andrei50497,

What type of information were you looking for, concerning Loc QA? I work with Localization here at our LAX office, I am happy to provide any insight into the position or answer any questions you may have
What is the biggest requirement and how important is previous QA experience?

So we look for many different aspects of a person when determining if they are a good fit for any position. What kind of culture fit are you? Are you an avid gamer, or at least do you play games on a semi consistent basis, do you work well with your team, can you kick ass on your own if need be? How do you handle conflict, and can you get results under ambiguous or sub optimal conditions. There are so many facets and areas we look for when considering someone for a position. While some of those have parallels across different positions, each position has different characteristics that the hiring manager is looking for, as noted by some of the examples above.

Is having prior QA experience a plus? Most definitely, however, it’s not a deal break if you don’t. That said, you should have some solid amazing skills to make up for any lack of experience. For localization QA we want people that understand the needs of the local offices. Can you recognize that certain words, names, lore, etc may not be best suited for that area? How do players in that area identify with the content we intend to ship there? Localization is one of the most important aspects of connecting players to our game; it’s more than just a direct translation. Loc QA is about ensuring what goes out the door makes sense, is culturally relevant, non offensive, and delivers an amazing experience for the player. 

In the long run, prior experience is a “great to have, not a must have”. People can be coached, mentored, and leveled up. Just because someone may lack a piece of the puzzle isn’t a reason for Riot to turn someone away. We always look for driven, amazing people that come from all different paths. 

We have former lawyers, nurses, prior military, artists, etc that work in our QA organization, and each one of them brings an astounding set of skills that we need in order to deliver a product that truly works to achieve our vision of becoming the most player focused gaming company in the world. 

Sorry this was a bit long-winded, but I wanted to try and capture the type of person we are looking for in any position we hire. I hope this helps

Cheers!

There's multiple sides to Localization QA. We have a number of Analysts in this role around the world who make sure that our game is well translated and tailored to the region that they're responsible for. We do our best to make every player feel like they're getting a great experience, and Localization QA is a huge part of that.

Some of Loc QA is focused on testing, some on managing localization, and more. It really depends on the needs of the moment as to what the role could be - but that's the general scope. I'll see if someone from Loc might be able to drop by to speak more on this.

Hey there Sean, to being I'm just going to say that I have high aspirations for working at Riot. I've applied to internships for two years now, applied to a few job positions and, while nothing has come from it, I do have a few Rioter friends who do vouch for me when it comes to cultural references ("Yeah he's definitely a fit here in terms of the kind of people Riot looks for!")

I'm primarily a writer but I'd love to help Riot in any capacity or way. So with that said, here are a few questions I have that will influence if I apply for this position or not:

* 1.) How much experience or previous work do you feel applies to QA? Do you feel this is a great job that I can get with only a little-to-no experience or do you feel that I should have several, very specific qualifications?


* 2.) As I said, I'm primarily a writer. Do you think there's a quality team that I can contribute to with this skill at all? 


* 3.) I'm a diehard league fan (Played since MF release) and decently ranked (Bronze/Silver/gold in Season 1/2/3, respectively). Does this meet expectations? Fall short? Go above and beyond in terms of Rioters?


* 4.) I currently live in Florida and I'm a student, but as I said I am very serious in working at Riot. Would my position hurt in getting this job? Would Riot consider it bad that I am willing to forgo some education for the sake of working at Riot? (Not to say dropping 100% "never going to school again" but I'd certainly be taking less/no classes to dedicate myself to this position)


* 5.) What do you consider the ideal candidate for any of these QA positions? Someone intelligent with a lot of experience? Someone who has an enormous drive to improve league and riot for the community? Someone who games day-and-night and lives n' breaths video games themselves?


* 6.) Would it be possible to add you on the in-game client or in twitter to further discuss this along with a tad more personal information? As much as I'd like to, putting some more real-life info on the forums isn't the best.


Like I said, I'm very serious about working at Riot and even if this position isn't right for me, I assure you that you -will- hear about me someday. Above all else, I owe it to both Riot and the community of League to make this game go even further and grander in scale.

In regards to number 2, I did a lot of technical writing before I started at Riot and had a ton of writing samples that I was able to present during my interview process.

This experience has served me VERY well when I need to communicate with players or when we're looking to create a better experience for players when they contact us.

There are definitely teams that love people who can write very well.

Technical writing as in papers and more professional samples/writing code or do you mean straight writing-writing (No rules anything goes.ooavi)

Nice seeing you at Riot vs. Community, btw!

Straight-up writing. Proper usage of soft skills, passive voice, plain-text language, etc. I speak with a lot of players on a daily basis, and it's incredibly important I'm able to properly communicate with them. Lots of folk are frustrated because they've been punished or they've had a poor experience in-game caused by other players. I want to help.

I don't want to derail the QA folk, though, so perhaps another AMA can happen sometime in the future with my team. I'm off for now!

PS Thanks for having me! I was so sad to not get that penta in the last game D:
I'd hardly say this is derailing the thread, though I can see why you think that. Still, it's very good to know proper writing skills are something that can be used in such a place.

As QA lets say.. for content, when gathering information from users' feedback, what percentage is weighed when gathering feedback? Is feedback data only gathered from League of Legends Forums and Reddit? Do you guys also get feedback from other sites as well to direct towards new content or content changes? What about feedback on your social media sites are those taken into account as well?

I personally leverage our forums/reddit the heaviest when looking for information. I know the content guys and gals read the crap out of the PBE forums when new skins/champions hit. We also have more datasciencey type things that mad scientists here create. Things like the little survey that pop up in the airclient.

Hi Pixie Poro!

There is no percent per se - we gather feedback from many sources, and not just the ones you mentioned.  Play tests, win rates worldwide, our forums, reddit...we don't ignore sources of feedback, but no single one tells the whole story either.
Good reply and thank you so much for answering, Riot Spider! =) I appreciate you both doing this Q&A. Thanks again!

What kind of specialities are required to get into QA?

What classes should I take at college for anything videogames?  

Computer Science is a must, and I know people like Lyte have other degrees, so what else can I focus my time on (other than LoL) when I'm not at school/doing schoolwork?

Lastly, how big is the QA department, and how demanding is it to work in QA?

Specialties:

This is very dependent on what you want to do. We have QA folks that work with the skins team, they generally have some sort of graphic design/art/ect. background. We have guys that are writing tools and automation, which would be a Computer Science/software engineering major. We also have guys working with live design/champion design that have solid problem solving/feedback/analysis skills. Those skills typically manifest from playing the game at a high level and degrees like philosophy/computer science/engineering/math.

Classes:

Focus on what you want to be doing longterm. Being an effective communicator and having a technical skill definitely helps. Great engineers are hard to come by. If you want to be working in the art emphasis, spend time building a portfolio (this is mostly out of my wheelhouse)


Whatelse:

I would find and digest books about the software development life cycle. Books like "How google Tests code" and "Crucial Conversations" are both decent reads. It is also incredibly helpful to have work you have completed. Work on a side project outside of normal classes. This gives you great topics to talk about during an interview and shows you can accomplish things.
